title: Thursday, 21st July, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:07 am
PM

Hi there

BE

Hooray!

PM

We are

11:08 am

BE

Apologies if you're trapped elsewhere. Hopefully you'll join us in time.

11:08 am

Which makes this session even more exclusive than usual, I guess.

hmm

11:11 am

(Firstname dot lastname at FT.com )

11:12 am

Ok. Shall we start again?

11:13 am
undefined
PM

PM

Haruhiko Kuroda

11:14 am
BE

..... okay.

PM

He's not having Albert Edwards predict his policy

PM

The yen has strengthened nearly 1 per cent against the dollar after Bank of Japan governor Haruhiko Kuroda poured cold water on hopes the central bank could resort to so-called “helicopter money”.

With the BoJ meeting for its next monthly policy meeting next week, Mr Kuroda said there is “no need and no possibility” to embark on a policy to inject direct stimulus into the veins of the economy or the pockets of consumers in a programme for BBC Radio 4 by the FT’s Martin Wolf.

The dollar is down 0.92 per cent against the yen at publication time at ¥105.91 per dollar. The yen had earlier been in negative territory against the greenback on the day amid media reports that policymakers were considering stimulus measures at the upper end of the previously forecast ¥10tn-¥20tn range. Japan’s currency is also 1 per cent stronger against the euro at publication time.

Mr Kuroda, who has in the past surprised markets, added that policymakers were still poised to carry out more conventional easing in the form of ramped up quantitative easing and cutting interest rates further into negative territory “if necessary”:

11:15 am
PM

That's from Fast https://next.ft.co...-ab12-58b7c869eeb7

PM

And here's Albert from this morning....

PM

I always thought the next global recession would force central bankers to climb into their
helicopters, but we are getting mighty close to the abandonment of all pretence of monetary
rectitude. It seems eminently plausible that on Ben Bernanke’s recent visit to the Bank of
Japan he left sufficient bottles of his own patented monetary kool-aid for the Bank of Japan to
cross the Rubicon early. A brave new world awaits of direct, off-balance-sheet monetary
alchemy. If only we had thought of this earlier. Actually I think it has been done before!

11:16 am
PM

Although the stronger than expected rise in June US payrolls certainly gave a big boost
to risk assets at the start of the month, it was Ben Bernanke’s visit to the Bank of Japan on
11 July that pushed macro-scribblers into a frenzy of excitement.
We can only speculate what ‘Helicopter’ Ben might have been talking to BoJ Governor
Kuroda about. Surely, only one thing? At last, the ‘copters are being readied and central
bankers can drop this disingenuous flimflammery of whether or not their QE easing
programmes are really monetisation. Let’s cut the crap and get down to the real deal.

PM

There is even talk that the imminent Bank of Japan meeting on 28 July will go to the outer
limits of monetary alchemy and discuss issuing a zero-coupon perpetual bond. Now don’t
get me wrong, I’m all in favour of perpetual government bonds. Indeed I used to hold the UK
Government’s perpetual 3½% War Loan, issued in 1917 to finance the UK’s WW1 spending.
But at least I actually used to receive a bi-annual coupon for doing my bit for the war effort
that is until that pesky George Osborne redeemed it after almost 100 years, proving that
unlike diamonds, perpetual government bonds are not forever. Maybe I’m getting old, or on
the wrong medication, but I just can’t get my head around this brave new world where we
lend the insolvent Japanese government our hard-earned money to receive nothing back
from them, forever! We could just give it to them. But one thing is clear it is only a matter
of time till US 10y yields converge with Swiss, Japanese and German bond yields in
negative territory.

PM

Good stuff, eh?

11:17 am
PM

I find myself increasingly drawn to the Albert camp

PM

But I'd better not share any more. Contact SocGen for the full Edwards monty

A full auction has begun with GlaxoSmithKline, Sanofi and Galenica of Switzerland among the potential bidders, the people said.

easyJet plc (EZJ:LSE): Last: 1,054, down 73 (-6.48%), High: 1,094, Low: 1,041, Volume: 3.46m
11:38 am
PM

Carolyn McCall, easyJet Chief Executive said:

"We remain confident in the strength of easyJet's business model and our ability to continue to deliver our successful strategy and our leading returns. We have today written to the UK Government and the European Commission to ask them to prioritise the UK remaining part of the single EU aviation market, given its importance to trade and consumers."

PM

That's from June 24, of course

http://www.investe...1607210700098039E/

11:39 am

BE

Well, indeed. Is it the market? Or is it Easyjet's failures to make the planes take off on time and lacking enough ground crew to deal with the awkward detail of loading on the passengers?

BE

I mean, I flew with them twice. So that's double sourced.

11:41 am
BE

Let me grab some sellside to show what's happening to forecasts.

PM

So the last time I flew easyjet, i was appalling at all the people trying to get on the plane first -- so I hung back and sauntered on near to last. Then learnt why everyone was pushing forward -- there's not enough room in the cabin for hand luggage, so my little bag had to go in the hold, which took an extra hour out of my holiday to Montpellier.

PM

Sure, share some sell side

11:42 am
BE

Yep, that's right. And they try to convince people to put their hand luggage in the hold at the desk "for free".

BE

As if that's some kind of bonus. As if waiting 90 minutes at Luton or Gatwick is a benefit when you're already two hours late.

BE

Here's Deutsche.

11:43 am
BE

We see consensus down 8-10%
easyJet has reported its Q3-16 IMS today for the year ending Sep-16. Unusually for this juncture in the year management has not issued FY16 PBT guidance. In light of significant sector uncertainty given Lufthansa’s profit warning last night (click here), the lack of PBT guidance and H2-16 revenue per seat guidance will likely create negative pressure. Consensus FY16 PBT is £580m – which we believe assumes c-6% cc revenue per seat – and in our view this could fall to around the £520m level. We do not expect shares to fall this much however.
Q3 performance in-line with reduced guidance, Q4 weak
Q3 yield performance has come in broadly as guided (warned) on 27th June 2016. Constant currency revenue per seat is down 8.3% versus the 8.6% guided. For Q4 however preliminary bookings (65%) have Q4 cc revenue per seat down c7.5%. This is weaker than expected since in June management guided to H2 RPS cc down "at least mid single digit". Hence Q3 -8.3% and Q4 preliminary looking like -7.5% feels a bit weaker. If we were to assume H2 RPS was around 8% down that would get us to the £520m number stated above for where consensus might fall to.

BE

Cost guidance unchanged, board still committed to 50% payout
EZJ has made no change to its cost guidance – it has been reiterated at FY cc cost per seat ex-fuel down 1%, albeit caveated by "subject to normal levels of disruption". This is a normal caveat, however one of the reasons for the weak results are that disruption is much higher than usual. The Board has said it remains committed to its dividend policy of 50% payout of net income, however we believe management will be asked questions about whether this will require capex budget cuts and/or hedging of sterling cash reserves.
Why the yield weakness?
Quoting from the statement: “The economic and operating environment remains uncertain, following the high levels of disruption and more recently the UK’s referendum decision to leave the EU, as well as the recent events in Turkey and Nice, which have affected consumer confidence. This combined with industry capacity growth in short haul continues to have an impact on industry yields at a peak time of year." To us it sounds like a combination of short-haul overcapacity, significant disruption and consumer confidence weakening. We actually don’t think the first point is necessarily wholly new but the deterioration in consumer confidence is a serious concern if it does not improve. We expect management teams will be seriously considering major capacity plan reductions near-term.

BE

And Credit Suisse, which downgrades.

11:44 am
BE

4Q pricing down 7.5% currently and risk seems to the downside,
downgrading to Neutral: EZJ has confirmed an 8.3% revenue per seat
decline in 3Q at constant currency (7.7% on a reported basis) driving a 2.6%
decline in total revenue to £1,196m. Crucially, 4Q RPS is down 7.5% yoy for
the 65% of bookings already in place for the period, with uncertainty
preventing EZJ from providing FY16 PBT guidance. We cut our FY16E PBT
by 24% to £528m with 4Q pricing down 8% (each 1% move in RPS in 4Q
means £17m to PBT), and factoring in incremental fuel and FX tailwinds. EZJ
is a structural winner, well positioned to ultimately benefit from UK market
turmoil as weak demand pressures weaker competitors lacking EZJ's cost
structure and balance sheet. Yet earnings estimates clearly need to come
down across the market and distinct uncertainty around 2017E, where we
model a 2% PBT decline versus 5.5% growth per Reuters, prompts us to
downgrade EZJ to Neutral with a new TP of 1,130p.

BE

Difficult to grow earnings in 2017: We are concerned that pricing will prove
particularly weak in winter (EZJ's 1H17) with plans to grow by 8-9%, and
model pricing down 5% at constant currency in FY17 which more than
absorbs a likely c£200m fuel bill tailwind. As such, we forecast FY16E PBT of
£528m falling to £518m in FY17E. Further, we highlight our FCF forecast
falls to £115m in FY16E, £227m in FY17E (including c£200m disposal
proceeds from 25 A319 SLSBKs) and a negative £140m in FY18E. EZJ held
net cash of £368m at the end of June.
■ Target price down 24% to 1,130p, downgrading to Neutral: We value EZJ
based on a blend of multiples (EVIC 1.7x, EV/EBITDAR 6.0) and our DCF
model (midcycle EBIT margin 11.5%).

BE

Note also the Lufthansa warning.

11:45 am
BE

FY16 to turn negative YOY.

BE

On a third-quarter deterioration.

BE

Blames terrorists.

11:46 am
BE

In a statement, the company notes that “advance bookings, especially on long-haul routes to Europe, have declined significantly, in particular due to repeated terrorist attacks in Europe and to greater political and economic uncertainty since the original forecast was made in March”. The company is now expecting RASK ex-FX in the second half to fall by 8-9% (we had been assuming -6.5%). Ex-fuel unit cost guidance is given as -2 to -3% ex-FX in H2 2016, however, this benefits significantly from a lack of strike costs in Q4 (we had been assuming -3.5% ex-fuel CASK). As part of the release, Lufthansa has pre-released results for H1 2016: Adjusted EBIT was €529m, we had been forecasting €570m.

BE

So ....

International Consolidated Airlines Group SA (IAG:LSE): Last: 403.70, down 17 (-4.04%), High: 417.80, Low: 401.80, Volume: 9.41m
11:46 am
PM

11:48 am
BE

Yeah, true. I guess.

BE

Here's Credit Suisse (again) on the IAG read through.

BE

LHA warning highlights deteriorating pricing trends, cutting 2016E-
2017E EBIT to €2.5bn-€2.1bn and downgrading to Neutral: Following
Lufthansa's profit warning, we cut our IAG 2H unit revenue forecasts from a
4% decline to a 7% decline at constant currency, which compares to LHA's
8-9% guidance driven by weaker demand on long haul routes. This drives
our 2016E EBIT down 11% from €2.8bn to €2.5bn and our 2017E EBIT falls
by 17% to €2.1bn encompassing a 5% unit revenue decline. We continue to
view IAG as a compelling medium term self-help story. However escalating
revenue risk is likely to drive material downgrades for 2016E-2017E over the
coming months (we are now 13%-26% below Reuters EBIT consensus) and
we downgrade to Neutral with a TP of 439p (down 17%) as we await clarity
on the outlook for long haul premium demand. We continue to prefer IAG to
Underperform-rated Air France KLM and Lufthansa on self-help grounds and
view Outperform-rated Ryanair as the most defensive play in the sector.

11:49 am
BE

Confidence falling and premium revenue risk escalating: CS's Executive
Panel published an ad hoc post-Brexit corporate survey on 13 July (Taking
back control…or losing control?), highlighting a sharp fall in intentions for
corporate spending in the UK, while IATA's July 2016 Airline Business
Confidence Index (14 July) reflects deteriorating yield expectations and an
expectation among airline CFOs that yields will fall slightly more than input
costs on a global basis over the next 12 months. We remain conscious that,
beyond peak season, September/October will prove a pivotal period to more
fully understand the softening outlook for long haul premium travel.

BE

Target price down to 439p, downgrading to Neutral: Our TP represents a
blend of our multiples-based approach (EV/IC 1.35x, EV/EBITDAR 4.5x) and
our DCF model (incorporating a midcycle EBIT margin of 10%). On our
updated estimates, IAG trades on a 2017E EV/EBITDAR of 4.9x and an
EV/IC of 1.2x compared to a ROIC/WACC of 1.5x.

BE

Neil Glynn the analyst.

11:49 am
undefined
BE

(@Milky: have you really gone from punting Lloyds to punting Bitcoin? Because that must be some kind of negative indicator.)

BE

So ...... What else do we have? I'm quite far away from a price screen.

11:51 am
PM

(Negative for Lloyds or bitcoin or both?)

PM

AO World

PM

rocket

11:51 am
BE

(Negative for humanity in general.)

AO World PLC (AO.:LSE): Last: 144.87, up 10.47 (+7.79%), High: 148.90, Low: 139.00, Volume: 545.85k
BE

Yes, okay. AO World.

11:52 am
BE

Let's ignore that the reported figures are irrelevant

BE

PM

Come on, it's a really solid IMS

11:52 am

http://www.investe...1607210700107985E/

PM

ah, this is true

11:53 am

BE

Until we get some kind of clarity on Article 50 and all that jazz.

BE

So, yeah, AO World's rallied a bit on what's happening in the rear view mirror.

11:54 am
BE

The fact that management repeat FY guidance means only that it's not yet seen a slowdown.

BE

Is it sensible to think this will continue to be the case? To me. no. But whatever.

BE

Jefferies incoming.

11:55 am
BE

AO confirmed the 31 March FY16 pre-close print this morning, no major
changes. Bigger focus should be on the FY17 guide: UK revenue in line with
CONe, EBITDA slightly ahead. Europe revenue below by double digits, EBITDA
in line. Looking ahead, UK visits up +15.4% in Q117, so far stacking up well. AO
on a c.33% discount to peers' 2016E EV/Sales, Buy.

BE

That's an important point as well. AO's mostly telling the market what it's already reported.

BE

I'm lost as to why this is worth 8%.

11:56 am
PM

9% now

BE

Today's FY16 print. Group revenue +25.7% to £599.2m. AO.com up +27.7%, £487.1m,
total UK +18.6% to £558.5m. Europe revenue £40.7m, up from £5.9m last year. Group adj.
EBITDA loss -£3.9m from a FY15 £8.5m profit. UK adj. EBITDA of £17.2m, margin 3.1% from
3.5%. Europe adj. EBITDA loss -£21.1m. The Group was profitable in H216.
The FY17 guide. UK revenue £630m to £650m, in line with CONe; adj. EBITDA to be
slightly ahead, £21m to £25m. Europe, with its more controlled expansion, revenue €90m
to €110m (mid c.£78m) materially behind CONe, but adjusted EBITDA loss between €26m
and €30m (mid £22m) is still in line with CONe as they realise synergies and better deals
from suppliers. Overall, Group adj. EBITDA flipping to an implied £1m profit in FY17.
Closing cash. In our preview note (here), we discussed cash, perhaps a concern for the
bears. With their simple cash model, we thought they would end the year with £28m cash;
they actually ended on £33m. So, along with the new five-year £30m RCF announced today,
we are very comfortable with the company's cash position.
Updating our numbers for FY17. UK revenue goes up +1.6% to £640.9m, YoY +14.8%,
Europe revenue halved to £78.0m, YoY +91.6%. UK EBITDA up +15.8% to £22.0m, lower end
of guide, Europe EBITDA loss increased by +14.8% to -£23.0m, higher end of guide. Group
revenue down -9.1% to £718.9m, YoY +20.0%, but EBITDA holds steady at a -£1.0m loss.
What do we think? A good set of results to finish the year, very pleased with the format
of the FY17 guide. A revenue range and EBITDA positioning. Something for the bulls and
the bears. Reduced revenues in Europe as the company focuses on operational efficiencies.
But what falls out is an in-line or slightly improved adj. EBITDA for the Group, along with a
solid cash position, bolstered with the £30m RCF, and the launch of computing in the UK
and floor care in DE.

undefined
11:58 am
PM

William Hill quickly before we finish?

William Hill PLC (WMH:LSE): Last: 290.70, up 15.6 (+5.67%), High: 290.80, Low: 273.40, Volume: 5.55m
BE

Sure, if you wish. Now there's a business in difficulty.

11:59 am
PM

James Henderson in 'shock' exit

PM

Except it's not a shock

BE

11:59 am
PM

BE

PM

12:00 pm
PM

BE

Well, yesterday I was having a poke around the various options for those wishing to lose their money.

BE

Do you know about BetConstruct?

12:01 pm
PM

BE

It's giant. Huge. Gigantic. There are thousands of sites running off its code.

12:01 pm
BE

Have you ever heard of fartbet.com?

BE

Yes, that's an actual site. Fartbet.com.

PM

Great

12:03 pm
PM

PM

PM

https://en.wikiped.../wiki/BetConstruct

12:03 pm
PM

BE

BE

12:04 pm
BE

My local WillHill has giant neon-yellow posters in its windows encouraging its customers not to gamble.

BE

Meanwhile, there are a few thousand sites running on Betconstruct and similar platforms that don't need such niceties as they're rattled together in 15 minutes, and can close down just as quick.

PM

12:05 pm
PM

BE

Were I the CEO of William Hill, I'd be looking elsewhere right now as well.

BE

Brokers mostly saying ...... "well, this isn't good news, is it?

12:06 pm
BE

Barclays.

BE

William Hill have announced that James Henderson, CEO, will step down with immediate effect. Philip Bowcock (CFO) will be interim CEO and the search for a permanent CEO replacement is underway. The company states that Mr Bowcock’s principal priority is the “continued turnaround of the Online Business”. We wrote extensively around this potential turnaround in our note, William Hill; One for the Contrarians (7th June 2016). Positively, the company confirm that “trading is in line with previous guidance of £260-280m” of EBITA in 2016 (Barclays £264m) – we view this as positive news given that WMH has delivered 2 years of EPS downgrades. As we have said recently, stability in earnings was required for investors to start focusing on the SOTP discount that WMH is trading at vs. peers. WMH is undergoing structural, managerial and technological change at a time of intense competition and ongoing risks from negative regulation. However, on a 5 year view, we see the UK gambling market consolidating to c. 6 key players: we think WMH will be 1. WMH is trading on a P/E of 11.8x, EV/EBITDA of 8.7x and offers a Dividend Yield of 4.5%.

BE

Understandable pushback to our OW rating – Some investors may view William Hill as a ‘value trap’. 1) Online amounts wagered growth may not improve putting further pressure on earnings and holding back a re-rating. 2) We understand that earnings momentum is unlikely to improve in the short term. We appreciate some investors may wait to see signs of trading improving before investing (and this may not happen until H2 17). 3) We appreciate that given William Hill has seen nearly 2 years of EPS downgrades, stability in earnings may be required to give investors greater confidence in focusing on a SOTP.

12:07 pm
BE

And Credit Suisse.

BE

Management change designed to enhance leadership credentials rather
than reflecting trading: William Hill has announced the departure of its
CEO James Henderson with the CFO Philip Bowcock to take on the role of
interim CEO with immediate effect. Weaker performance of late from its
online business has been the key investor focus and the Chairman's
statement today emphasizes the turnaround of online as the clear priority.
Regrettably, in our view, William Hill has experience too much management
change in recent years with the outgoing CEO having only been in his role
for 2 years, the CFO and now interim CEO only having joined in November
2015 and changes in the management of William Hill Online (MD Crisin
Nieboer only in place permanently since May 2016). However, with FY16
EBIT guidance of £260-280m retained (CSe: £269m), we don't interpret the
management change as being linked to any deterioration in trading but rather
the Board taking steps to strengthen the online credentials of senior
management – although we believe the process of finding a permanent CEO
may well take 12 months.

BE

Shares already experienced a significant de-rating: The share price has
been disappointing YTD given the March warning and this has led to a 12m
fwd PE de-rating from 15x in early 2016 to 11x today (based on Bloomberg
consensus). We retain an OP rating seeing good value in the shares at this
level, whilst fully acknowledging patience will be required before new
management and hence complete strategic clarity are in place.
